page.title: 06BIRDLIFE IN SOUTH DEVON cont
page.content: near humans,chaffinches who nest near grassland and their cousins the goldfinches who are migrant visitors.Summer visitors are swallows and housemartins,who build their mud nests in the eaves of buildings.We also see blackbirds and thrushes,and at ploughing time the tractors are followed by a variety of gulls.Perhaps most beautiful are the soaring buzzards,not a rare bird here,often seen perching on telegraph poles watching for small rodents to eat.Even more often seen is another, smaller bird of prey, the kestrel, who nests on nearby cliffs or in high trees or derelict buildings. Birdwatching is a fascinating hobby which is made more enjoyable in South Devon by the wide variety of species found here.
